_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Kemps Ice Cream Company, located in, Rochester, MN, is a production facility offering a range of dairy products. Kemps Ice Cream uses Anhydrous Ammonia as a refrigerant at this facility to provide cooling for the production and storage areas. The Kemps Ice Cream refrigeration system is a closed loop system with normal operating pressures that range between a low side of 3" hg to a high side of 135 psi. The systems maximum intended inventory is 65,000 pounds.



ANSI/IIAR-2 Standard for Equipment, Design, and Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigeration Systems.

ANSI/ASHRAE 15-1992 Safety Code for Mechanical Refrigeration.

ASME/ANSI B31.5 Refrigeration Piping Code.

ASME Boiler and Pressure Vessel Code.

International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) Bulletin 110 - Startup, Inspection and Maintenance of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigeration System.

International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) Bulletin 116 - Guidelines for: Avoiding Component Failure in Industrial Refrigeration Systems Caused by Abnormal Pressure or Shock.

 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:   

The Kemps Ice Cream Company is a non-responding facility, therefore it is not required to have an Emergency Response Plan. However, the company has developed and implemented an Emergency Action Plan as required by OSHA under 29 CFR 1910.38.                                                                       The Kemps Ice Cream Company is subject to the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know Act (EPCRA), part 68 for having a regulated toxic substance over the threshold quantity. Under EPCRA and being a non-responding facility, the Kemps Ice Cream Company is required to be included in the community's emergency response plan developed the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The company has coordinated efforts with the Rochester Fire Department (LEPC) to establish an emergency notification and the execution of the company's emergency action plan. 

The

company has established annual plant wide evacuation drills to assure all employees are prepared to evacuate the facility in the event of an ammonia release. The Plans and procedures are periodically reviewed and at least annually to assure that they are current and up to date.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following: 



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 



? On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

? Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))." 



An investigation into the facility's accident history revealed that there has been one release over the previous five years (May 2016 - May 2021) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in 24 hours or that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History.



On June 19, 2020, the 135 HP Reciprocating Compressor (HS-1) failed, releasing approximately 1,319 pounds of ammonia. At approximately 23:05 pm, an ammonia sensor alarmed at the facility. At 23:20, the ammonia system was shut down and the compressor was isolated. At 23:23 Employees were evacuated. At 23:30, the Fire/Hazmat Department arrived on site. At 23:40, At 23:40, PSM Coordinator notified company's Emergency Contacts. At 00.01, NRC was notified about the ammonia release and case #1279986 was assigned. At 00.05, MN Duty Officer was notified and case #191980 was assigned. At 00.10, Emergency Services left the property and employees returned to work. 



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

OSHA Process Safety Management

EPA Risk Management Program

OSHA HAZWOPER Program

ASME Boiler & Pressure Valve Codes

ANSI B31.3 Piping Code

IIAR Industry guideline for safety an

d good engineering practices

NFPA guidelines for fire protection equipment



Kemps Ice Cream through regular audits, training, maintenance, testing and inspections programs has established a history of safe operation and that the community emergency action plans are current and in place. Also that training with community services has been done and is on going. This is to ensure that in the event of an accidental release the Kemps Ice Cream trained personnel and the community emergency services can minimize the release and stop it with no impact to the employees or the community.
